... then he gets another physical by the state, and he makes his appearance before the judge. That should take four hours if we're lucky, then we're on our way.

I see.

Hi, Tommy.

... and the book ends, but what Samuels is really talking about here is fate.

You see, fate caught up with several lives here. No matter what course of action Rollins took, he was destined to his own fate, his own day of reckoning with himself. The idea is that destiny is a very real, concrete thing that every person has to deal with.

LAURIE'S POV - STREET

She turns away from the window and begins to doodle again.

ANGLE ON LAURIE
She glances up from the book and out the window again.
LAURIE'S POV - STREET
The shape behind the station wagon is still there and staring right at her.

She frowns, staring back at the shape.

No, not since Thursday. Yes, yes, I'm all right... Stop worrying. After this I’ll sleep for a week, two weeks... I said I'm all right... Believe me. I'll be home soon. Yes, I do. Very much. I just... have to stop him.

Calm down. This is ridiculous.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Old graveyard on a windy hillside, a car pulling up

SCRIPT.LINE: Wide shot of an old graveyard on a windy hillside.

Camera booms down as a car pulls up on the small road in f.g. Sam Loomis gets out, along with Taylor, the graveyard owner. Taylor is a small, officious man in his late sixties. He glances at a small note pad.
Let’s see. Myers. Judith Myers. Row 18, plot 20. Over this way.
The two men begin walking along through the graveyard, winding around headstones and flowers.

Every town has something like this happen. I remember a guy over in Russellville. Charly Bowles. About fifteen years ago, he finished dinner, excused himself from the table, went out into the garage and got a hack saw, then came back into the house, kissed his wife and two children goodbye, and then proceeded to...
Where are we?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Taylor stops cold, pointing to a plot where the headstone is missing

SCRIPT.LINE: Just right over there a ways. And I remember Judith Myers. Just couldn’t believe it. A young boy like that...
Taylor stops cold.
Lost?
Why do they do it?
He points to a plot right in front of them. Loomis stares. The headstone is missing, uprooted from the ground.
Goddamn kids. They'll do anything on Halloween.
Whose grave is it?
18.. 20... Judith Myers...
Taylor gives Loomis a quizzical look. Loomis shakes his head and looks out across the graveyard.
He came home...

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Trees lining a residential street, twisting and writhing in the dusk wind, Laurie waiting by the street with a totebag and a pumpkin, pale sun behind trees

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera begins on the trees that line the residential street, twisting and writhing in the dusk wind. Slowly camera booms down to Laurie waiting outside her house by the street. She carries a totebag with schoolbooks and knitting needles stuck inside, and a large pumpkin. The sun is a pale glow behind the trees.
Laurie turns her gaze down the street.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: More children in costumes walk from house to house, some with mothers and sisters, trick or treating; the wind blows their costumes

SCRIPT.LINE: More Children in costumes walk from house to house, some with Mothers and Sisters, trick or treating; The wind blows their costumes, billowing them outward.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie watches trick or treaters as a car swings around the corner and pulls up in front of her. It is Annie.

SCRIPT.LINE: She watches the trick or treaters as a car swings around the corner and pulls up in front of her. It is Annie.
Hurry up.
Laurie walks around to the passenger door and gets in.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Annie pulls away from the curb and hands Laurie a joint

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie pulls away from the curb and hands Laurie a joint.
We just have time.
Laurie lights the joint and puffs vigorously.
You still spooked?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie responding to Annie's question
Driving at dusk

SCRIPT.LINE: wasn't spooked.
Lies.
I saw someone standing in Mr. Riddle's back yard.
Probably Mister Riddle.
He was watching me.
Mister Riddle was watching you? Laurie, Mister Riddle is eighty-seven.
He can still watch.
That's probably all he can do.
Behind them through the rear-view mirror, we see Loomis' station wagon pull out of an alley and follow along.
What's the pumpkin for?
I brought it for Tommy. I figured making a Jack-O-Lantern would keep him occupied.
I always said you'd make a fabulous girl scout.
Thanks.
For that matter, I might as well be a girl scout tonight. I plan on making popcorn and watching Doctor Dementia. Six straight hours of horror movies. Little Lindsey Wallace won't know what hit her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dusk, main square, Annie's car and a station wagon

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie's car drives through the main square of Haddonfield. Following behind is the station wagon.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Driving, approaching police cars

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie points up ahead and quickly hides the joint.
My dad!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dusk, two police cars, alarm bell inside ringing

SCRIPT.LINE: POV THROUGH WINDSHIELD

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Windows rolled down, clearing smoke

SCRIPT.LINE: They quickly roll down the windows and begin wildly clearing out the marijuana smoke. Behind them the station wagon disappears off down a side-street.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dusk, police cars, Brackett speaking to Annie and Laurie

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie's car stops at the police cars. Lee Brackett strolls out to the car and leans down to the window.
Hi, Annie, Laurie...
Hi, Dad. What happened?
(strains to hear over the alarm)
What happened?
Someone broke in the hardware store. Probably kids.
You blame everything on kids.
The only things missing were some Halloween masks, rope, a set of knives. What does that sound like to you?
Annie turns to Laurie.
It’s hard growing up with a cynical father.
Behind Brackett, Sam Loomis walks up the street. We see Loomis talk to a COP who points over to Brackett.
You’re going to be late at the Doyles, Annie.
(unable to hear over alarm)
Just as Brackett is about to speak the alarm goes off.
(shouts)
(to Laurie)
Brackett smiles as Loomis walks up behind him.
Goodbye, girls.
Bye.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Street with police cars, Loomis and Brackett talking

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie's car pulls away.
Sheriff? I'm Doctor Sam Loomis.
Lee Brackett.
As they talk CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES AROUND THEM to a view of the street.
I'd like to talk with you, if I could.
May be a few minutes. I gotta stick around here...
It's important.
Loomis station wagon moves by behind them. Loomis doesn't see it.
Ten minutes.
I'll be here.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Full moon rising through blowing trees

SCRIPT.LINE: Through the blowing trees we see the full moon rising in the night sky. There are SOUNDS of wind and CHIRPING CRICKETS.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Quiet residential street, night, Annie's car arrives

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie's car moves down a quiet little residential street and pulls up in front of a two-story house set back from the street: the Doyle house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Street view from station wagon, Annie's car and Doyle house

SCRIPT.LINE: ANGLE FROM STATION WAGON
Then Annie's car makes a wide U-turn in the street and starts down the other direction. The station wagon pulls forward and follows her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Street with station wagon, Annie pulling into garage, Wallace house

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie stops three houses down the street and pulls into a garage. The station wagon stops several feet away.
We see Annie come out of the garage and walk to another two-story frame house: the Wallaces.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: The Shape exiting station wagon, looking at Wallace house

SCRIPT.LINE: TRACKING SHOT BEHIND SHAPE
The shape moves. CAMERA TRACKS behind him as he walks toward the Wallace house.
The shape stops in front. Through the front room windows we can see Annie talking to the WALLACES as they put on their coats.
The front door opens. CAMERA and shape quickly move behind a tree to hide from sight.

The Wallaces step out of their house and walk to the garage. Annie and LINDSEY WALLACE, a pretty little nine-year-old, stand in the doorway framed by the hall light. Out of the garage comes the Wallaces' car. It turns and disappears down the street.
Annie closes the door. The shape seeps out from behind the tree and stares at the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior view through window, Annie watching TV and brushing hair

SCRIPT.LINE: ANGLE ON WINDOW

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Night, police car arriving

SCRIPT.LINE: A police car pulls up in front of the Myers h

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Side of a dilapidated house with a front gate

SCRIPT.LINE: Brackett and Loomis get out and stand by the front gate.
Anybody live here?
Not since 1963, since it happened. Every kid in Haddonfield thinks this place is haunted.
They may be right.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Looking down the side of the house towards the porch

SCRIPT.LINE: Looking down the side of the house we see Loomis and Brackett walk up to the front porch. A broken, rusted rain gutter CLANGS back and forth against the house in the wind.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark interior of a house, doorway

SCRIPT.LINE: The front door slowly opens. Brackett and Loomis stand in the doorway. They glance at each other. Brackett draws his gun and the two men step inside.
It is totally dark in the house. Brackett's flashlight comes on, illuminating the two men. As they move through the house CAMERA TRACKS with them.
Suddenly Brackett stops. He trains his flashlight on a small object in the corner of the room.
What is it?
For a moment Brackett doesn’t speak. Then he steps closer to the object.
A dog...
Both men look down off screen at the animal. Brackett bends down to it.
Still warm.
He stands back up and looks at Loomis.
He got hungry.
Brackett gets a disgusted expression and steps away.
Come on... A skunk could have killed it...
Could have...
Brackett looks back at the dead animal.
A man wouldn't do that...
He isn't a man.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bedroom with shadows from streetlights and blowing trees

SCRIPT.LINE: Loomis and Brackett cautiously step into the bedroom, the same room where the murder took place fifteen years ago. The glow from a distant streetlight casts the shadows of blowing trees on the walls.
It happened in here.
Loomis walks over to the spot where the sister was sitting.
She was sitting here when he came through the door.
Loomis turns and glances at the window. He slowly walks toward it.
He must have watched them through this window...

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Looking through the window from inside the room

SCRIPT.LINE: CAMERA SLOWLY TRACKS IN toward the window.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bedroom with a shattered window

SCRIPT.LINE: Loomis stops by the window.
Standing just outside, he could peer over the sill...
Blown loose by the wind, the rain gutter suddenly swings down and SMASHES through the window with a THUNDERING CRASH of broken glass.
Loomis jumps back, reaches into his coat pocket and draws a .357 magnum revolver.
Brackett stares at him. Loomis sees Brackett's reaction and slowly reholsters the revolver.
I suppose I do seem a bit sinister for a doctor.
Looks like to me you're just plain scared.
I am.
(he glances around the bedroom)

I met him fifteen years ago. I was told there was nothing left, no conscience, no reason, no understanding, in even the most rudimentary sense, of life or death or right or wrong. I met this six-year-old boy with a blank, cold emotionless face and the blackest of eyes, the devil's eyes. I spent eight years trying to reach him and another seven trying to keep him locked away when I realized what was living behind that boy's eyes was purely, simply evil.
Brackett just looks at him a moment.
What do we do?
He was here, earlier tonight, and he may be coming back. I'm going to wait for him.
I keep thinking I should call the radio and TV stations...
If you do they'll be seeing him everywhere, on every street corner, in every house. Just tell your men to shut their mouths and open their eyes.
I'll check back in an hour.
Brackett turns and walks out of the bedroom. For a moment Loomis stares at the rain gutter in the broken window.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Living room with couch, staircase, kitchen entrance

SCRIPT.LINE: CAMERA SLOWLY TRACKS through the Doyle house. It is a large home with a staircase that leads to the bedrooms upstairs. Through a doorway we see a very modern kitchen. There is a dining room and living room with a big bay window that looks out into the street.
Laurie sits with Tommy Doyle on the couch reading him a story. Tommy has his Halloween costume on and a big bag of candy on the floor.
"how now, cried Arthur. 'Then no one may pass this way without a fight?' 'That is so,' answered the knight in a bold and haughty manner..."
I don't like that story.
But King Arthur was always your favorite.
Tommy pulls out a stack of comic books from underneath the couch.
Not any more.
Why are they under there?
Mom doesn't like me to have them.
Laurie glances through the stack of comic books.
'Neutron Man'... 'Laser Man'... I can see why. 'Tarantula Man'...
Laurie, what's the Boogey Man?
The phone RINGS in the other room. Laurie goes to answer it. She picks up the receiver in the den.
Hello.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Modern kitchen with Annie making popcorn

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie stands making popcorn, the phone at her ear.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Daytime, domestic setting

SCRIPT.LINE: Having fun? Never mind, I'm sure you are. I have big, big news for you...
Lester, a large, ferocious-looking German shepherd, trots happily into the kitchen, spies Annie and walks over to her. He nudges her legs with his head.
Oops! Hold on a minute...
She turns and reaches for Lester uncertainly.
Hi Lester...
GROWLS at her menacingly.
Lindsey, Lindsey!
(into phone) I'm about to be ripped, apart by the family dog...
Lindsey trots into the room.
Get him out of here!
Here, Lester.
Immediately Lester walks over to the back door. Lindsey opens the door and the dog Crocs out. Then Lindsey closes the back door and walks back into the living room.
(into phone) I hate that dog. I'm the only person in the world he doesn't like.
(V.O. phone) What's this big, big news?
What would you say if I told you that you were going to the Homecoming Dance tomorrow night?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, living room

SCRIPT.LINE: I’d say you must have the wrong number.
Well, I just talked with Ben Tramer and he got real excited when I told him how attracted you were to him.
Annie, you didn't. Tell me you didn't.
You guys will make a fabulous couple.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, front window

SCRIPT.LINE: Tommy walks to the front window and looks out.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, street view from window

SCRIPT.LINE: A couple Trick or Treaters walk by. Behind them, across the street, stands the shape, looking into the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, street view from behind the shape

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera is behind the shape, looking into the Doyle house. We can see Laurie talking on the phone. The shape's head moves slightly and we pan to see Tommy at the front room window looking out. Tommy moves away from the window. Pan back to see him enter the den and pull on Laurie's blouse.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, den

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie...
(into phone) I'm so embarrassed. I couldn't face him...
You'll have to. He's calling you tomorrow to find out what time to pick you up.
Annie!
Laurie, the bogyman is outside. Look!
Tommy runs to the window in the den and points. Laurie walks over with the phone and looks:

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, street view from den window

SCRIPT.LINE: The street is empty.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, den, Laurie and Tommy

SCRIPT.LINE: (into phone) Hold on. (to Tommy) There's nobody there, Tommy. Go watch some TV.
Tommy runs out of the den.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, front window

SCRIPT.LINE: Tommy dashes up to the front window and looks out.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, street view from Tommy's perspective

SCRIPT.LINE: We see the man as he passes under a streetlight on his way toward the Wallace house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, kitchen

SCRIPT.LINE: (into telephone) Look, it's simple. You like him, he likes you. All you need is a little push.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, view into kitchen

SCRIPT.LINE: The shape stands close to camera watching Annie make popcorn. She puts the butter in the pan.
It won't hurt you to go out with him, for God's sake.
Annie stares to pour the butter over the popcorn but instead pours it on herself.
Shit! No, no, I gotta call you back. I just made a mess of myself. Nothing unusual.

Annie hangs up. She quickly cakes off her blouse and blue jeans. She stands in the kitchen with only her panties on. She pulls a box of cornstarch out of the closet and sprinkles it out on the stains of butter.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, side of the house

SCRIPT.LINE: The shape moves closer to the kitchen window and knocks over a potted plane. It CRASHES noisily against the side of the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, near kitchen window

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie is startled by the crash. She looks outside the window.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, view into kitchen window

SCRIPT.LINE: A hanging plant swings in the wind. It BUMPS against the side of the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, Annie near kitchen window

SCRIPT.LINE: She turns from the window and walks out of the kitchen.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, side of the house

SCRIPT.LINE: The hanging plant continues to WRAP against the house. A hand suddenly stops its motion. The shape leans up close to the kitchen window, looking inside.
From the darkness of the back yard Lester springs forward into CAMERA, SNARLING and BARKING viciously.
The shape darts away from the kitchen window, the dog SNAPPING right after him.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior, living room

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie listens to the GROWLING of the dog. She turns to Lindsey in the living room.
Lindsey, Lester's barking again and getting on my nerves again.
(o.s.) No, he's not.
Suddenly the GROWLING sounds abruptly stop.
Never mind. He found a hot date.
Annie turns and walks into the living room.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Exterior, side of the house at night

SCRIPT.LINE: We see the shape's legs a few feet from the house. Next to him are Lester's legs, kicking and struggling a few feet above the ground.
Off screen, the shape is strangling the dog in mid-air. Finally the dog’s legs stop moving and dangle lifelessly. The shape moves a

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, a horror movie marathon is playing on TV, two children on a couch.

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie and Tommy are sitting on the couch watching the Horrorthon on TV.
What about the Jack-O-Lantern?
After the movie.
What about the rest of my comic books?
After the Jack-O-Lantern.
What about the bogyman?
There's no such thing.
Richie said he was coming after me tonight.
Do you believe everything that Richie tells you?
No...
Tommy, Halloween night is when you play tricks on people and scare them. It's all make believe. Richie was trying to scare you.
I saw the bogyman. I saw him outside.
There was no one out there.
There was.
What did he look like?
The bogyman!
We're not getting anywhere. All right, look, Tommy. The bogyman can only come out on Halloween night, right?
Right.
And I'm here tonight and I won't let him get you.
Promise?
I promise.
Can we make the Jack-O-Lantern now?
Laurie holds out her hand. Tommy takes it and together they walk into the kitchen.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, narrow, dimly lit passageway leading to a laundry room.

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie walks through the passageway to the laundry room. She is wearing a nylon robe and carrying her clothes to be washed. The wind blows the robe open.
The shape stands behind a tree watching Annie walk along the passageway.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, dark, old-fashioned laundry room with a washing machine.

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie walks into the dark laundry room.
Almost immediately the wind blows the door shut!
Annie stands motionless for a moment, then begins looking for the light switch.
Terrific!
The door creaks open. Behind the door we see the outline of the shape standing there.
Annie turns toward the slightly opened door.
Hello?
Silence.
Who’s there?
Silence. The wind blows the door open a little wider.
In the light from the main house, Annie sees the light switch. Quickly she flicks on the switch and the laundry room lights up. She glances outside the door.
There is no one there.
Paul, is this one of your cheap tricks?
(pause; disappointed) I guess not.
She steps back inside and crosses to the washing machine. She opens the top and dumps her clothes inside.
No tricks for Annie tonight.
Suddenly a big gust of wind comes through the opened window above her. The door slams shut!
Annie hurries to the door and tries to open it. It won't open.
She tries to pull the door open. Behind her, in the open window above the washing machine, we see the shape looking in.
Lindsey! Lindsey, come out here!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, a horror movie marathon is playing on TV at high volume.

SCRIPT.LINE: Lindsey Wallace, 8 years old with a pretty face, watches the Horror Marathon at top volume on TV. She doesn't hear Annie's call.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Annie is stuck halfway out of a window, panicked.

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie, I'm in the laundry room! The door is stuck!
Annie turns and glances at the window above the washing machine. The shape is gone.
She quickly crosses to the washing machine, climbs up on top of it and starts out the window. Half way through she gets stuck. She tries to squirm her way back in but it's hopeless.
Lindsey! Lindsey, goddamn it, help!
From the house Annie hears the phone ring.
Lindsey, answer the phone! It's Paul! Lindsey! LINDSEY!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Lindsey is watching TV, the phone rings.

SCRIPT.LINE: Lindsey still sits in front of the TV. She lets the phone ring away. Finally she gets up and walks to the phone, her eyes pivoted on the TV. She picks up the receiver.
Hello.
Hi, Lindsey, this is Paul. Is Annie there?
Yes, she is.
Will you get her for me.
She's washing her clothes.
Well, go tell her it's me, okay?
Okay.
Lindsey hangs up the phone and walks through the kitchen to the back door. She calls from the door.
Annie, Paul's on the phone!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Annie is stuck halfway out of a laundry room window.

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie, Paul's on the phone!
Lindsey, open the door! I'm locked in the laundry room!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, Lindsey is at the laundry room door, Annie is stuck in the window.

SCRIPT.LINE: Lindsey crosses to the laundry room door. It is bolted from the outside. She lifts the bolt and looks inside the room.
You locked yourself in.
I know. Pull my legs. I'm stuck.
Lindsey pulls on Annie's legs and she slides from the window onto the dryer.
Lindsey, promise you won't tell anyone!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, the phone rings, Lindsey answers it.

SCRIPT.LINE: As Annie and Lindsey walk back inside the house, the phone rings. Lindsey races across the room and picks it up.
She was stuck in the window, she'll be right here.
Lindsey sets down the receiver and walks out of the kitchen. Annie gives Lindsey a dirty look and picks it up.
Hello, Paul. All right, cut it out. It can happen.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dimly lit hallway, shadows

SCRIPT.LINE: Suddenly behind Laurie the shape walks through the hallway between the living room and the kitchen. She doesn’t see it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Not specified

SCRIPT.LINE: That's fantastic! When did they leave?
Utterly fabulous! So why don't you just walk over?
My clothes are in the wash. I can’t come now.
Shut up, jerk. I've got a robe on. That's all you think about.
That's not true. I think about lots of things. Why don't we not stand here talking about and get down to doing them? All right, see you in a few minutes.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Living room with TV on, lights off

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie hangs up the phone. She walks into the living room. Lindsey is back watching the TV Horrorthon.
I'm scared.
Then why are you sitting here with the lights off?
I don't know.
Well, come on, get your coat. We're going to pick up Paul.
I don't want to.
Look, Lindsey, I thought we understood each other...
I want to stay here and watch this.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Living room, Annie thinking

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie calculates a moment.
Okay, if I can fix it so you can watch TV with Tommy Doyle, would you like that?
Yes.
Come with me.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime street, wind blowing

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie and Lindsey come out of the Wallace house. Lindsey carries a bowl of popcorn. Annie has a coat over the negligee.
They walk down the street to the Doyles. The wind blows strong and whips the negligee around Annie's legs.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Streetlight glow, dark surroundings

SCRIPT.LINE: As the girls make their way down the street. The shape steps into the glow of the streetlight and watches them. He pulls a large knife from his pocket. The blade glistens in the light.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Living room with pumpkin carving mess, doorbell

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie and Tommy are covered with pumpkin meat when the doorbell rings. Tommy runs to answer it. He opens the door. Annie and Lindsey stand there.
Hi, come on in. We’re making a Jack-O-Lantern.
I want to watch TV.
Lindsey sees the TV on and runs into the living room. She takes off her coat; sits in front of the TV and eats her popcorn.
Fancy.
This has not been my night. My clothes are in the wash, I spilled butter down the front of me, I got stuck in a window...
I'm glad you're here because I have something I want you to do. I want you to call up Ben Tramer and tell him you were just fooling around.
I can't.
Yes, you can.
He went out drinking beer with Mike Godfrey and he won't be back until late. You'll have to call him tomorrow. Besides, I'm on my way to pick up Paul.
Wait a minute here...
If you watch her, I'll consider talking to Ben Tramer in the morning.
Deal. Hey, I thought Paul was grounded.
He was. Old jerko found a way to sneak out. Listen, I'll call you in an hour or so.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Doorway, Annie leaving

SCRIPT.LINE: Before Laurie can say anything else, Annie rushes out the door. Laurie closes the door and looks in at Tommy and Lindsey engrossed in the Horrorthon.
The old girl scout comes through again.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark garage, car visible

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie hurries across the back yard and steps into the garage. She walks to her car.
Oh, Paul, I give you all...
She tries the door. It is locked.
No keys, but please... my Paul.
Quickly she turns and walks out of the garage.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Hallway or living room, mirror visible

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie wanders through the empty house looking for her purse. She finds it in the front room, takes out her brush and lipstick and stands in front of the mirror primping.
My Paxil, I can no longer stall...
Lucky thing. Spilled butter on her clothes, but nobody will know... except for Paul...
Suddenly the phone RINGS. Quickly Annie grabs it.
Hello. Oh, hi, Dad.
No, just watching TV with Lindsey.
Be careful about what?
Well, if you won't tell me how can I be careful?
Sure, sure I will. Bye, dad.
She hangs up, grabs her purse and rushes out the door.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Garage, car visible, door unlocked

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie walks into the garage, over to her car and opens the door. It is now unlocked, but Annie doesn't notice.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Car interior, night

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie slides in and inserts the key in the ignition. The car starts. Annie glances at the car door lock. Suddenly she remembers it was locked. She stares at it, puzzled.
An instant later, a man sits up in the back seat. He wears a Halloween mask made of rubber with the grotesque features of a man. He reaches forward and grabs her.
SCREAMS.
She lurches for the door. The men puts one hand over her mouth and brings the huge butcher knife up to her thro

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Inside a car, interior covered in condensation, viewed from outside

SCRIPT.LINE: From outside the car we see the struggle inside. Annie's anguished face presses against the steamed window. Her screams are muffled by the closed car.
Suddenly, the struggle stops.
Annie's face slides down the car window leaving a track in the wet surface. Then slowly the track in the glass steams over again.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Living room, TV playing 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers', night

SCRIPT.LINE: Music from Invasion of the Body Snatchers fills the room. Lindsey and Tommy are riveted to the screen.
Tommy glances at Lindsey and slowly sneaks away from the couch. He jumps to a window and ducks behind a curtain.
Lindsey. Lindsey.
Lindsey turns around and looks for Tommy.
Where are you?
No answer. Lindsey gets up from the couch to search for Tommy.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Behind a curtain, looking out a window

SCRIPT.LINE: Tommy hides, preparing to jump out and scare Lindsey. For a moment, he glances out the window.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark backyard, figure carrying a body

SCRIPT.LINE: The figure of a man carries what seems to be a body across the Wallace's back yard.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Living room, Lindsey and Tommy crying, Laurie enters

SCRIPT.LINE: Tommy SCREAMS and jumps out from the curtain, scaring the hell out of Lindsey, who also SCREAMS and begins crying.
There he is, there he is! The bogyman!
Laurie rushes in from the kitchen finding the children in tears.
What's wrong?
Tommy points out the window.
I saw him again! He’s over at Lindsey's house. The bogyman!
At this, Lindsey begins to CRY even louder. Laurie bends down to comfort her.
Tommy, stop it! You’re scaring Lindsey.
I saw him...
I said, 'stop it! There is no bogyman. There's nothing out there. If you don't stop all this, I'm turning off the TV and you go to bed.
Tommy turns away from Laurie and Lindsey and walks over to the couch in front of the TV set. Almost instantly, Lindsey stops crying and follows him.
Nobody believes me.
I believe you, Tommy.
Lindsey sits up next to Tommy and hugs him. Laurie shakes her head and walks back into the kitchen.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Old, dilapidated house silhouetted against dark trees, night

SCRIPT.LINE: The old Myers house looks ominous and foreboding silhouetted against the dark, whispering trees. CAMERA TRACKS behind the hedge to where Loomis sits waiting.
Suddenly, there are noises from the street. Loomis parts the hedge in front of him and stares.

SCENE.LOCATION: Street in front of Myers House (Loomis' POV)
SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark street, three boys at the edge of the sidewalk looking at the house

SCRIPT.LINE: Three boys, Keith, Richie and Lonnie (from the playground) creep up to the edge of the sidewalk in front of the old house. They stare fearfully at the dark, tomb-like structure.
I'm not afraid.
Bullshit.
I'm not!
Then go in.
For a moment Lonnie hesitates, then slowly moves through the front gate up toward the porch.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: View of Lonnie walking towards the house, Loomis watching from behind a hedge

SCRIPT.LINE: He watches the young boy walk toward the house, unsure whether he should interfere or just watch.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Lonnie at the front door, looking back at his friends

SCRIPT.LINE: Lonnie makes it to the front porch and tentatively steps up to the door. He glances back to his friends in the street.
Richie: Chicken! Keith: Go on, Lonnie!
The boy turns to open the door. He's scared out of his mind.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Loomis observing Lonnie at the front door

SCRIPT.LINE: Loomis' POV moves back to Lonnie at the front door. The boy turns to open the door. He's scared out of his mind.
Loomis quietly stands up behind the hedge.
Lonnie...

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Lonnie spinning around, seeing Loomis, then running

SCRIPT.LINE: Lonnie spins around and stares in horror at the talking hedge.
Get your ass away from there!
Moving like the wind, Lonnie barrels off the porch and races back to his friends. The three boys hurtle off down the dark street in utter terror.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Loomis standing behind a hedge, smiling

SCRIPT.LINE: He watches them race away, smiling to himself.
Suddenly, two hands enter frame and grab Loomis' shoulders. Loomis jumps and spins around. Standing there is Brackett.
Jesus!
You all right?
Sure...
Nothing's going on. Just kids playing pranks, trick or treating, parking, getting high... I have the feeling you're way off on this...
You have the wrong feeling.
You're not coming up with much to prove me wrong.
Exactly what do you need?
Well, it's going to take more than fancy talk to keep me up all night creeping around these bushes.

I watched him for fifteen years, sitting in a room staring at a wall, not seeing the wall, seeing past it, seeing this night. He's waited for it, inhumanly patient. Hour after hour, day after day, waiting for some silent, invisible alarm to trigger him. Death has arrived in your little town, sheriff. You can ignore it, or you can help me stop it.
More fancy talk... You want to know what Haddonfield is? Families. Children, all lined up in rows, up and down these streets. You're telling me they're lined up for a slaughterhouse.
They could be...

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dimly lit bedroom, rumpled bedsheets

SCRIPT.LINE: Showing a very beautiful young body. Her hair is a mess and she is frustrated. The phone continues to ring.
I can't help it. It just keeps ringing.
And I can’t keep you interested?
Should we answer it?
Bob opens a fresh can of beer. He chugs it down.
That's great. Now you'll be too drunk to...
Just answer the damn phone.
I can’t. What if it's the Wallaces!? We'd get Annie in trouble.
The phone stops ringing.
Take it off the hook.
Lynda reaches over and kisses Bob behind the ears. She slowly moves around his ear with her tongue. Bob grabs Lynda and pushes her down on the bed.
Camera moves back from the bed as their lovemaking continues, back through the bedroom doorway. Standing there in the darkness is the shape watching them.
Finally, Bob and Lynda climax. Bob rolls off Lynda. She lights a cigarette and hands it to Bob, then lights one for herself.
Fantastic. Totally.
Yeah.
Want a beer?
Yeah.
Is that all you have to say?
Yeah.
Go get me a beer.
I thought you were gonna get one for me.
Yeah?
Bob gets out of bed and pulls his jeans on. He looks for his glasses. He finds them and puts them on.
I’ll be right back. Don’t get dressed.
Bob leans over and kisses Lynda. He leaves.
She smiles to herself.

PATHS.CHOICE: Bob goes to the Wallace kitchen

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime, clean, well-equipped kitchen

SCRIPT.LINE: Bob comes through the swinging doors. He opens the refrigerator and takes out two beers. He looks around the kitchen. He opens some cupboards and takes out a bag of potato chips. In another cupboard, he finds a can of peanuts.

Bob gathers the food and beers into his arms. He shuts out the light with his elbow. He turns to leave the doors. WHAM! He slips into a chair, knocking him backwards. The beer falls on the floor along with the chips and peanuts. Bob leans down to pick them up.
Goddammit!
Bob has his head down, intent on cleaning up the mess. There is a SLAM from across the kitchen. Bob looks up.
BOB'S POV - DOOR. The back door of the kitchen slowly swings open, as if it has been slammed shut and the bolt didn't catch. It squeaks on its hinges as it swings back and forth.
Slowly, Bob gets to his feet and walks over to the door.
Annie, Paul...
He steps to the door and looks outside.
BOB’S POV - BACK YARD. The yard is empty. Just the wind blowing the trees.
He turns from the door.
There is a SQUEAK from one of the two closet doors by the kitchen counter.
Bob freezes, staring at the two doors.
Lynda, you asshole!
He walks to one of the doors and opens it. Nothing inside.
All right, Lynda, come on out.
He steps to the other door and opens it. Right behind the door stands the shape wearing the rubber mask. He steps out and grabs Bob around the neck in an instantaneous lunge.
Bob tries to jump away, but the shape has a firm hold on his neck. Bob coughs and gags from the pressure.
Then the shape lifts Bob up off the floor.
ANGLE ON BOB'S FEET. Bob's feet leave the floor.
ANGLE ON BOB'S FACE. He makes a guttural sound deep in his throat as the shape's hand closes, tightly around his windpipe.
ANGLE ON SHAPE. Behind the mask are two burning eyes. The shape moves forward.
ANGLE ON WALL. Still holding him up with one hand the shape slams Bob against the wall, holding him up several feet off the floor. Bob struggles to get free.
The shape lifts his other hand. It holds the butcher knife.
The shape drives the knife deeply into Bob's chest with a slamming thud, the other end of the knife stuck through the wall.
Then the shape steps away. Bob hangs there, impaled on the wall, eyes still open in horror, dead.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bedroom lit by candles, Lynda on the bed

SCRIPT.LINE: Lynda lounges on the bed smoking another cigarette. She hears Bob enter the room but doesn't look up.
Where's my beer?
No answer. Lynda turns around and looks.
ANOTHER ANGLE - LYNDA'S POV. The shape stands in the doorway. He is covered with a sheet like a ghost. He wears Bob's glasses.
Cute, Bob. Real cute.
The ghost doesn't answer.
ANOTHER ANGLE - LYNDA AND GHOST. Lynda looks at the ghost. She slides the sheets down from her body.
Come here, you fool.
The ghost doesn't answer. He continues to stare at Lynda.
Can’t I get your ghost, Bob?
Lynda laughs at her own joke, then stops when she sees the ghost is motionless.
All right, all right. So where's the beer.
Nothing. The ghost just stands there.
Well, answer me! Okay, don’t answer me. Boy, are you weird!
Lynda gets out of bed. She is nude and looks beautiful and sensuous in the candlelight.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Lynda by a phone, ghost in doorway

SCRIPT.LINE: She walks over to the phone.
Well, I'm gonna call Laurie. I wanne know where Annie and Paul are. This isn't going anywhere.
Lynda sits down on a chair by the telephone. In the b.g. the ghost stands in the doorway. She starts to dial the phone. The ghost starts walking toward her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Kids asleep, Laurie knitting on couch, phone rings

SCRIPT.LINE: The house is very quiet. The kids are asleep. Laurie is sitting on the couch knitting. The phone RINGS.
Finally.
Laurie crosses to answer the phone.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Lynda on phone, ghost approaches from behind

SCRIPT.LINE: Lynda holds the phone to her ear. The ghost walks up slowly behind her. He raises his hands to grab her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie answers the phone

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie answers the telephone.
Hello.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Ghost attacks Lynda, grabs phone

SCRIPT.LINE: Lynda hears Laurie’s hello as the ghost grabs the phone. He clamps one hand over Lynda’s mouth. She squirms and writhes. He takes the telephone cord and wraps it around her neck.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie hears strange sounds on the phone

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie hears SQUEALS, and rustling sounds across the phone.
All right, Annie! I’ve heard your famous chewing, now I get your famous squeals?
Laurie continues to hear weird SOUNDS.
Annie?

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Lynda struggles, ghost reveals mask, Lynda dies

SCRIPT.LINE: Lynda tries to fight off the ghost. He wraps the cord around her neck. He pulls tight. Lynda reaches up and pulls on the sheet. It slides off of the man, to reveal the grotesque Halloween mask.
Lynda gasps and tries to scream. The man pulls the cord tighter. Her face turns blue. She opens her mouth, trying to get air, then slowly slumps forward and remains motionless. Lynda is dead.
The shape picks up the receiver and puts it to his ear.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie on the phone, hears silence

SCRIPT.LINE: Annie, Annie! Are you all right?
Silence over the phone
Are you fooling around again?
Silence.
I'll kill you if this is a joke!
More silence.
Annie...
Suddenly the phone goes dead.
Laurie stares at the receiver, then hangs up. She crosses to the window and looks out toward the Wallace house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Street quiet, dark, windy, Bob's car parked, light on in bedroom, then off

SCRIPT.LINE: The street is quiet, dark and windy. Bob's car is parked in front of the Wallace house.
Suddenly a light goes on in the bedroom.
Then the light goes off.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie moves from window, dials Annie's number

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie moves from the window back to the telephone and dials Annie's number. We HEAR the phone ringing on the other end.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Camera tracks through dark, empty bedroom, phone rings

SCRIPT.LINE: CAMERA SLOWLY TRACKS through the darkened bedroom of the Wallace house. There is no sign of a struggle. The room is empty. The phone RINGS away.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie hangs up, considers, goes upstairs

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie finally hangs up Che phone. She stands for a moment considering it, then turns and walks upstairs.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie opens bedroom door, sees sleeping children

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie opens the door to the bedroom. Tommy and Lindsey are sound asleep on the bed. She looks at them a moment, then closes the door behind her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie comes downstairs, takes key, goes to window

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie comes back downstairs. She takes a key out of her purse and again steps to the window.

PATHS.CHOICE: Laurie looks at Wallace house again

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Wallace house is dark and silent

SCRIPT.LINE: Dark and silent.

PATHS.CHOICE: Laurie goes to the front door

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Loomis watches Myers house from hedge, walks to street

SCRIPT.LINE: Loomis sits in silence behind the hedge watching the Myers house. Frustrated, he gets up and walks to the street.
For a moment he glances back at the Myers house, then starts down the quiet residential street.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Street empty except for a distant station wagon

SCRIPT.LINE: It is empty except for a station wagon parked several blocks away.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Loomis turns away, then looks back at the station wagon

SCRIPT.LINE: He turns away from the street. Then a thought strikes him. He looks again.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: The lone car is Loomis' station wagon

SCRIPT.LINE: The lone car is Loomis station wagon.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Loomis uncertain, slowly walks towards his station wagon

SCRIPT.LINE: He’s not certain of it. Slowly Loomis starts walking down the street toward the station wagon.

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie locks the Doyle house and walks away out into the street. The wind whips her clothes and hair.

SCRIPT.LINE: MOVING SHOT toward the Wallace house, dark and ominous.
A car turns the corner and drives past the Wallace house, casting a strange shadowy pattern across the front of the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie moves down the street, shivering, puts key in pocket

SCRIPT.LINE: She moves down the street, shivering in the chill wind. She puts the key to the Doyle house in her pocket.

SCRIPT.LINE: The house looms closer and closer.

SCRIPT.LINE: TRACKING SHOT with Loomis as he walks up the street.

SCRIPT.LINE: The station wagon moves closer.

SCRIPT.LINE: He recognizes it and races forward.

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera tracks in to the station wagon, right up to the state emblem emblazoned on the side.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime exterior of a house

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera moves up to the front of the Wallace house.
Laurie walks up to the front porch. She stands there a moment, listening, as if to hear some sound of life from the inside.
She knocks on the door and rings the doorbell. She waits. Silence.
She steps off the porch and walks around to the side of the house, camera tracking with her. She moves to the garage and peeks inside. There is Annie's car.
Laurie thinks a moment, then looks to the street.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Car parked on a street at night

SCRIPT.LINE: Bob's car sits there on the street.

SCENE.LOCATION: Angle on Laurie - Back to House
SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie walking towards the back of the house

SCRIPT.LINE: She turns and walks through the breezeway between the house and garage around to the back door.
The kitchen door is ajar, swinging back and forth in the wind.
Laurie pulls open the door and steps into the house.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark kitchen interior

SCRIPT.LINE: The kitchen is dark. Laurie stands there a moment staring into the blackness.
Annie?
No answer.
Bob, Lynda, Annie?
No one answers. Laurie searches for the wall light. She flips it and nothing happens. She looks again into the darkness.
Hello?
Nothing. Laurie moves forward into the house, camera tracking with her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Almost dark living room

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie walks into the living room. She stops to let her eyes get accustomed to the almost total darkness. She reaches for a nearby lamp and trips over the cord. The lamp clunks to the floor.
Shit.
Suddenly there is a crashing sound from upstairs.
Laurie spins around and stares up the dark staircase.
Another squeak from above.
Laurie smiles.
All right, meatheads. The joke is over.
Silence.
Come on, Annie, enough.
Another sound from upstairs, a dragging across the floor.
Laurie moves to the head of the staircase. The dragging sound stops abruptly. Silence.
This has most definitely stopped being funny. Now cut it out!
A scraping sound, then silence.
You’ll be sorry.
Slowly Laurie starts up the staircase.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Man looking around a dark street

SCRIPT.LINE: Loomis stands by his car glancing up and down the empty street. Finally he makes up his mind and starts moving down the street, almost running, looking back and forth at the rows of houses on either side for something out of place.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Slow tracking shot up a dark staircase

SCRIPT.LINE: Slowly tracking up the staircase.
Moving shot - Laurie as she slowly moves up the stairs. She reaches the top and stops.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark hallway with an orange glow at the end

SCRIPT.LINE: It is totally dark. At the end of the hall is the bedroom door. From around the edges of the door is the faintest orange glow.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie approaching a bedroom door

SCRIPT.LINE: She moves for the door, camera tracking with her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bedroom lit by a Jack-o-lantern

SCRIPT.LINE: She reaches the door. Her hand reaches out and touches it. The door swings open.
A Jack-o-lantern casts an eerie glow around the room. There, is someone lying on the bed but from this position Laurie can't see.

SCENE.LOCATION: Angle on Laurie - Moving to Bed
SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie moving closer to the bed

SCRIPT.LINE: She moves forward toward the bed.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: View of Annie on the bed with a gash across her throat, and a tombstone

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera moves forward. There on the bed is Annie! Her face is a chalky white and there is a huge red gash across her throat. At the head of the bed is Judith Myers' tombstone.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie screaming in horror

SCRIPT.LINE: She stares at the bed and then screams at the top of her lungs.
Suddenly something drops down at her from above. Laurie jumps, back to the door.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bob hanging from the ceiling light fixture

SCRIPT.LINE: Strung up to the light fixture on the ceiling, dangling there in the middle of the room, is Bob eyes open and staring.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Lynda standing in a doorway with dead eyes

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie backs out of the bedroom. Her mouth is open in speechless horror.
Suddenly a door next to her slowly opens. There is Lynda standing there, propped up by a chair, staring at her with glazed, dead eyes.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie in a dark corner, with the shape of the killer behind her

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie shrinks back into a dark corner. She can only stare in horror at the sight of her friend.
Suddenly we are aware of something there in the dark corner. It is almost as if our eyes have suddenly begun to adjust to the darkness and we see the outline of a man standing right behind her.
The outline becomes more and more clear. It is the shape, wearing the mask, the butcher knife in his hand, gleaming, right behind Laurie.
Laurie suddenly moves away from the corner.
The shape lunges out at her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Close up of a hand grabbing and ripping Laurie's blouse

SCRIPT.LINE: The hand grasps a piece of Laurie's blouse and riffs it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie turning and screaming

SCRIPT.LINE: She screams and spins around.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: The shape holding a piece of fabric, raising a knife

SCRIPT.LINE: He stands there holding up the piece of material, then raises the butcher knife and moves for her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie backing away, screaming

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera moves with her as she backs away, screaming at the top of her lungs.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: The shape lunging forward

SCRIPT.LINE: He lunges at her suddenly.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Knife slicing, close-up on arm

SCRIPT.LINE: The knife slices across her arm, ripping her flesh.
Laurie suddenly jumps backward, raising her arm instinctively.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie bumping into the railing

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie bumps back into the railing.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Shape lunging with knife

SCRIPT.LINE: He lunges again with the knife.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie leaping backward and slipping

SCRIPT.LINE: She leaps backward to avoid the blade and slips over the edge of the railing.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Camera plunging down and slamming into the floor

SCRIPT.LINE: Camera plunges down from the second floor and slams into the floor.
She hits the floor and rolls over, holding her leg painfully. Then she looks up at the staircase.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Shape moving to the top of the staircase and starting down

SCRIPT.LINE: The shape moves to the top of the staircase and starts down toward her.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie pulling herself up and hobbling into the living room

SCRIPT.LINE: She pulls herself up off the floor and hobbles into the living room.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Shape racing down the stairs

SCRIPT.LINE: The shape races down the stairs.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie moving for the kitchen, tripping on fallen lamp

SCRIPT.LINE: She moves for the kitchen. She trips on the fallen lamp and falls to the floor.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Shape stepping into the living room, knife raised

SCRIPT.LINE: The shape steps into the living room, knife raised.

I’m scaled...
DO WHAT I SAY! NOW!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: The Shape leaping from behind couch

SCRIPT.LINE: Suddenly the shape leaps up from behind the couch! He springs at her, plunging the butcher knife.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Butcher knife embedded in couch

SCRIPT.LINE: The blade of the butcher knife THUMPS into the couch.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie stabbing the Shape with knitting needle

SCRIPT.LINE: Instinctively Laurie raises the knitting needle and drives it home, right into the shape’s neck!
The shape springs backward, clawing at the needle, rolling his head back and forth. Then suddenly he freezes, hands outstretched, motionless, and falls in a heap on the floor.
Laurie sits there.
The shape doesn't move.
Laurie begins to cry again, harder and harder.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Street at night, police car

SCRIPT.LINE: CAMERA MOVES WITH LOOMIS as he moves along the street.
Suddenly two headlights hit him and a police car swerves to a stop next to him. Brackett gets out.
Where were you? I went back to the Myers house...
I found the car! He’s here!
Where?
Three blocks down. Get in the car and go up that other street then back down here. I’m going up the block.
Brackett turns and hurries back to the car.
Loomis starts up the street again as Brackett pulls off in the other direction.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie and motionless Shape in living room

SCRIPT.LINE: WIDE SHOT of the living room. Laurie is on one side of frame, the motionless shape lying behind the couch on the other.
Slowly Laurie stands up, stares at the shape and then moves to the staircase.
Slowly, painfully, Laurie climbs up the stairs.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Children huddled in corner, Laurie enters

SCRIPT.LINE: Tommy and Lindsey are huddled in a corner WHIMPERING softly. The door opens and Laurie steps in. The two children run to her CRYING. She holds them in her arms tightly and nudges the door shut with her foot.
It's all right now. Shhh, it's all right...
She takes the children back to the bed and sits down with them.
Now I want you to change your clothes, Tommy. We're going to take a walk outside.
Was it the bogyman?
I'm scared!
There's nothing to be scared of now. Get changed.
Are you sure?
Yes.
How?
I killed him...
But you can't kill the bogyman.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Shape entering bedroom, butcher knife raised

SCRIPT.LINE: Suddenly the bedroom door swings open. Standing there is the shape, the butcher knife raised.
Both children SCREAM. Laurie shoves them into the bathroom and pulls the door shut, leaving herself outside in the bedroom.
Lock the door! Lock the door!
The shape moves for her, slowly now, but relentless, the knife glistening.
There is a CLICK as the bathroom door is locked. Laurie leaps away from the door and circles around the bed.
The shape keeps coming.
Laurie dashes to a clothes closet and ducks inside.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie hiding in dark closet

SCRIPT.LINE: Laurie pulls the sliding doors closed and crawls back into the small, dark interior of the closet.
Suddenly the doors begin to buckle as the shape pounds on them.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie grabbing wire hanger

SCRIPT.LINE: She reaches up and grabs a wire hanger from the top of the closet. She rips off the shirt and begins unhooking it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Closet door buckling from Shape's assault

SCRIPT.LINE: The door buckles inward as the shape SMASHES against it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie straightening wire hanger

SCRIPT.LINE: She twists the top of the hanger, unwinding the wire.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Closet door breaking in

SCRIPT.LINE: The door BREAKS IN. The shape steps inside, pushing aside the clothes.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie holding straightened wire hanger

SCRIPT.LINE: She unhooks the hanger and bends it out straight.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Shape peering down at Laurie, knife raised

SCRIPT.LINE: The shape leans in, peering down at Laurie in the corner, raising the knife.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie thrusting hanger at Shape's eye

SCRIPT.LINE: Holding the hanger with both hands she thrusts it forward with all her might.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Wire hanger in Shape's eye, dropping knife

SCRIPT.LINE: The wire hanger flashes into the shape's right eye.
He leaps back in pain, dropping the butcher knife,, grabbing his eye with both hands.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie grabbing butcher knife

SCRIPT.LINE: She grasps the butcher knife with both hands and jabs it upward.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Laurie jabbing butcher knife upward at the Shape

SCRIPT.LINE: null

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Dark closet interior, then bedroom with Shape on floor

SCRIPT.LINE: The butcher knife plunges into the shape's mid-section, right down to the hilt. The shape stumbles backward out of the closet.
ANGLE ON LAURIE. She just sits there in the corner of the closet. There is a THUMP from the bedroom, then silence.
Slowly Laurie crawls around and peeks out of the closet doors.
LAURIE'S POV - SHAPE. The shape lies on the floor by the bed, the butcher knife protruding from his stomach.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Bedroom interior, Shape on floor, Bathroom door

SCRIPT.LINE: INT. BEDROOM. Laurie emerges from the closet and carefully crosses the bedroom, avoiding the shape's body. She goes to the bathroom door and knocks softly.
Tommy, it's me. Open the door.
There is a silence, then the door opens. On the other side are Tommy and Lindsey, looking utterly terrified. Laurie bends down and shields them from the sight of the shape.
Now, I want you to walk to the door, down the stairs and right out the front door.
You're coming with us...
Listen to me. I want you to walk down the street to the MacKensie's and knock on their door. You tell them to call the police and send them over here. Do you understand?
Laurie, you come with us...
No! Do as I say.

She stands up and guides the children carefully across the bedroom to the door and ushers them outside. She watches for a moment as they walk down the stairs, then slumps down against the door frame in an exhausted heap.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Nighttime exterior, kids running down street, Loomis observing

SCRIPT.LINE: EXT. DOYLE HOUSE - NIGHT. Tommy and Lindsey run out of the house and down the walk to the sidewalk. They rush up the street. As they leave frame we see Loomis on the other side of the street.
ANGLE ON LOOMIS. He watches the children with a puzzled frown.
LOOMIS' POV - TOMMY AND LINDSEY. Shrieking with fear, Tommy and Lindsey run up the sidewalk.
ANGLE ON LOOMIS. He stares at them for a moment, then moves for the Doyle house.

SCENE.LOCATION: Doyle House Interior - Angle Through Bedroom Door
SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Interior view through bedroom door, Laurie slumped, Shape on floor

SCRIPT.LINE: INT. DOYLE HOUSE - ANGLE THROUGH BEDROOM DOOR - NIGHT. We see through the bedroom door. In f.g. sits Laurie, slumped against the door frame, staring out at nothing; tears screaming down her face. In b.g. lies the shape.

Slowly Laurie begins to pull herself together once again. She gets up to her knees and begins to pull herself up to her feet. Her back is to the shape. As she starts to stand the shape sits up, the head turning to Laurie.

CLOSE SHOT - LAURIE. Laurie rises into frame, holding herself erect by grasping the door frame. Behind her the shape rises up into frame, quickly, silently. Laurie just hangs there on the doorframe. An exhausted, ironic smile comes over her face.
Well, kiddo. Some Halloween...
Slowly the shape moves for her, his hands outstretched. Just as he is about to grab her, Laurie manages to step out the door.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Hallway interior, Michael lunging, then Loomis appearing

SCRIPT.LINE: ANGLE IN HALL. Unaware he is behind her, Laurie limps toward the stairs. Suddenly the shape jumps out of the bedroom and grabs her, hands around her neck. Laurie SCREAMS. She twists and squirms and claws at him, her fingers ripping at his mask. She pulls it off over his face, wriggles out of his grip and turns around.

CLOSE SHOT - MICHAEL. The shape, Michael, stares at her with his one eye. He has a dank, white face with blond hair. There is something completely unhuman about his features, the open mouth, the dark staring eye.
ANGLE IN HALL. Michael lunges at her again. Suddenly there is a THUNDERING EXPLOSION and Michael is blown off his feet. Laurie falls back against the wall.
ANGLE ON LOOMIS. Standing at the top of the stairs is Loomis, gun in his hand. He moves forward down the hall.

ANGLE IN HALL. Michael slowly gets to his feet, still refusing to die. Loomis stops and takes aim. BLAM! BLAM! BLAM! Michael is hit three times, each bullet throwing him backward further down the hall until he hits the window at the end and SMASHES through it.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Upward angle of Michael falling from second story

SCRIPT.LINE: EXT. DOYLE HOUSE - UP ANGLE. Michael falls from the second story right down into CAMERA with a CRASH!

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Hallway interior, Loomis comforting Laurie, shattered window

SCRIPT.LINE: ANGLE IN HALL. Loomis rushes to Laurie and bends down beside her. For a moment she just cries in his arms, sobbing hysterically. Then she looks up at him with a glazed, wild expression.
It was the bogyman...
Loomis looks down At her, then up at the shattered window at the end of the hall.
As a matter of fact it was.
He walks slowly down to the window and peers out.
LOOMIS' POV - BACK YARD. He looks down at the spot where Michael should be, but there is nothing there, just a trampled patch in the grass.
ANGLE ON LOOMIS. He stares down with growing fear, then looks out from the house.
LOOMIS' POV. The back yard, the neighboring yards, the street, all are empty, quiet, dark. There is only the SOUND of the wind swelling in the trees. Michael is gone.

SCENE.BACKGROUND_EDIT: Black screen with rolling end titles

SCRIPT.LINE: FADE TO BLACK. ROLL END TITLES. THE END
